etymologies: late Middle English: from Old French, or from Latin consonantia, from consonant- ‘sounding together’, from the verb consonare (see consonant)

definitions: agreement or compatibility between opinions or actions

examples.text: consonance between conservation measures and existing agricultural practice

shortDefinitions: agreement or compatibility between opinions or actions

definitions: the recurrence of similar sounds, especially consonants, in close proximity (chiefly as used in prosody)

examples.text: the abrupt quality of the sound is echoed in the final “t” consonance of “discreet” and “shut”

shortDefinitions: recurrence of similar-sounding consonants in close proximity

definitions: a combination of notes which are in harmony with each other due to the relationship between their frequencies

examples.text: all music creates tension and release, dissonance and consonance
the tendency to place strong consonances in lower parts

shortDefinitions: combination of notes which are in harmony with each other due to relationship between their frequencies
